tn.text: This is another way of saying "temple of Yahweh."
These are all names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Hezekiah sent Eliakim"
"all wearing sackcloth"

tn.ref: This day is a day of distress
tn.text: Here "day" is synecdoche for a period of time. AT: "This is a time of distress" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the children have come to the time of birth, but there is no strength for them to be born
tn.text: This is a metaphor to describe how the people and their leaders have become so weak and unable to fight the enemy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Words" is synecdoche for the message of the words. AT: "the whole message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This a common way (an idiom) to use the action of lifting to metaphorically represent praying earnestly to Yahweh who is above us. AT: "pray earnestly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I will put a spirit in him, and he will hear a certain report and go back to his own land
tn.text: "I will control the attitude of the king of Assyria, so when he hears a report, he will want to return to his own country"

tn.ref: I will put a spirit in him
tn.text: Here "spirit" probably refers to his attitude and thoughts, rather than to a spirit being. AT: "I will influence his thinking" or " I will cause him to think differently"

tn.ref: I will cause him to fall by the sword
tn.text: "Fall by the sword" is metonymy for being killed. AT: "I will cause him to die by the sword" or "I will cause some men to kill him with a sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the official from Assyria in charge under the king"

tn.ref: found the king of Assyria fighting
tn.text: "discovered that the Assyrian army was fighting"
The names of cities in the kingdom of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"had prepared his army to fight against Assyria"
"so Sennacherib sent"
This message was written in a letter.
This is the message that King Sennacharib of Assyria sent to King Hezekiah.

tn.ref: Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you, saying
tn.text: "Do not believe your God in whom you trust. He is lying when he says"

tn.ref: the hand of the king of Assyria
tn.text: "Hand" is metonymy for control, authority or power. AT: "the control of the government of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Notice, you have heard" or "You have certainly heard" (UDB). Here "see" was used to draw attention to what he was about to say next.

Sennacharib used this question to emphasize that God will not be able to rescue them. AT: "Your God will not rescue you" or "You will not be able to escape either" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
King Sennacharib's message to King Hezekiah continues.

tn.ref: Have the gods of the nations rescued them
tn.text: This question assumes Hezekiah knows the answer and provides emphasis. AT: "The gods of the nations certainly did not rescue them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"the previous kings of Assyria" or "the armies of the previous kings of Assyria" (UDB)

tn.ref: Gozan ... Haran ... Rezeph ... Eden ... Telassar ... Hamath ... Arpad ... Sepharvaim ... Hena ... Ivvah
tn.text: These are all place names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to the letter that King Sennacherib of Assyria sent to Hezekiah. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:19:08]])
King Hezekiah continues praying to Yahweh after receiving the letter from King Sennacherib of Assyria.

tn.ref: Turn your ear, Yahweh, and listen. Open your eyes, Yahweh, and see
tn.text: Both of these sentences urge Yahweh to pay attention to the things that Sennacherib is saying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Turn your ear, Yahweh, and listen
tn.text: The words "Turn your ear" and "listen" mean the same thing and add emphasis to the plea. AT: "Yahweh, please listen to what he is saying." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Open your eyes, Yahweh, and see
tn.text: The words "Open your eyes" and "see" mean the same thing and add emphasis to the plea. AT: "Yahweh, please pay attention to what is happening." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: They have put their gods into the fire
tn.text: The Assyrian kings have burned up the gods of the other nations.
The Assyrians destroyed both the nations and the nation's gods.
King Hezekiah continues praying to Yahweh after receiving the letter from King Sennacherib of Assyria.
"I beg of you,"
"from the power of the King of Assyria" (UDB) or "from the armies of the King of Assyria."

"Virgin daughter is metaphor for the people of Jerusalem as if they are young, vibrant and beautiful. AT: "The beautiful people of Jerusalem" The term "daughter" was used to give personal characteristics to cities by some biblical writers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: The virgin daughter of Zion despises you and laughs you to scorn. The daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head at you.
tn.text: Both of these sentences intend to give the same meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"Daughter" is metaphor for the people of Jerusalem. AT: "The people of the city of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This action is a metaphor to represents disdain at the pride of the Assyrians. AT: "scorns you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: lifted up your eyes in pride
tn.text: "Lift up your eyes in pride" is metonymy for a haughty or arrogant facial expression. AT: "looked at very proudly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
An expression for the God of Israel, Yahweh.
This continues the message from Yahweh given by Isaiah, the prophet, to King Hezekiah concerning King Sennacherib. It uses parallelism throughout. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
To "defy" is to openly resist or mock.

tn.ref: I have gone up ... I will cut down ... I will enter
tn.text: These boasts made by Sennacherib could only be fulfilled by his army. The pronoun "I" represents by synecdoche all the forces under his control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: I dried up all the rivers of Egypt under the soles of my feet
tn.text: This is a hyperbolic metaphor to say that he could cross any river. "And by marching through the streams of Egypt, we dried them all up!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This continues the message from Yahweh, given by Isaiah, the prophet, for King Hezekiah concerning King Sennecherib.  It uses parallelism throughout. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Have you not heard how ... times?
tn.text: To make the point strongly this question assumes the listener knows the answer. AT: "Surely you know how ... times." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"cities that cannot be captured" or "cities surrounded by high walls" (UDB)

tn.ref: plants in the field, green grass
tn.text: This metaphor compares the weak victims of the Assyrian advance to fragile plants. AT: 1) "as frail as plants and grass in the fields" (UDB) or 2) "as weak as shallow rooted plants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the grass on the roof or in the field, burned before it has grown up
tn.text: This continues the metaphor comparing the weak victims of the Assyrian advance to fragile plants in difficult conditions for growing fully. AT: 1) "like grass before it has matured." or 2) "like grass before it has grown tall." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This continues the message from Yahweh, given by Isaiah, the prophet, for King Hezekiah concerning King Sennecherib.  It uses parallelism throughout. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"your angry shouting about me,"

tn.ref: because your arrogance has reached my ears
tn.text: "Ears" are metonymy for listening or hearing. AT: "because I have heard your proud words," (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will put my hook in your nose, and my bit in your mouth
tn.text: A "hook" and a "bit" (to control a horse) are metaphors for Yahweh's control of Sennacherib. AT: "I will lead you like an animal." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will turn you back the way you came
tn.text: That Sennacherib will return home before he can conquer Jerusalem can be stated clearly. AT: "I will make you return to your own country the same way you came, without conquering Jerusalem." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here Isaiah is talking to King Hezekiah.  He continues using parallelism throughout. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"grows without having been planted,"

tn.ref: The remnant of the house of Judah that survives will again take root and bear fruit
tn.text: This metaphor compares restoration of the remnant to plantings that take hold and produce results. AT: 1) "The people of Judah who remain alive will restore their lives and prosperity." or 2) "The people who remain in Judah will prosper and have many children." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The zeal of Yahweh of hosts will do this
tn.text: "The strong action of Yahweh will make this happen."
This is the end of the message from Yahweh, spoken through the prophet Isaiah to King Hezekiah.  It uses parallelism throughout. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"Arrow" is metonymy representing all tools of warfare and destruction. AT: "nor do any fighting here." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: or build up a siege ramp against it
tn.text: "and they will not even build up high mounds of earth against the city wall to enable them to attack the city." (UDB)

tn.ref: This is the declaration of Yahweh
tn.text: For Yahweh to "declare" is for Yahweh to promise or commit to what He said He will do.

tn.ref: for my own sake and for my servant David's sake
tn.text: "for the sake of my own reputation and because of what I promised to King David, who served me well." (UDB)
"It happened"
"when the men who were left alive got up the next morning"
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
